clinical_summary: Across reports from April to July 2025, the patient demonstrated markedly elevated conjugated bilirubin (7.79 mg/dL) with raised alkaline phosphatase (396 U/L) and gamma‑glutamyl transferase (263 U/L) indicating a cholestatic pattern; transaminases were modestly increased (AST 162 U/L, ALT 86 U/L). Hematology showed early‑April eosinophilia (8.1 %) and lymphopenia (16 %), while a July CBC revealed leukocytosis (WBC 14.0 ×10³/µL) with neutrophilia (82 %) and severe thrombocytopenia (platelets 22 ×10³/µL). Electrolytes were largely normal except borderline low potassium (3.48 mmol/L).

differential_diagnoses.name: Obstructive biliary disease (e.g., choledocholithiasis)
differential_diagnoses.justification: High conjugated bilirubin with markedly elevated ALP and GGT suggests cholestasis due to biliary obstruction.

differential_diagnoses.name: Drug‑induced cholestasis
differential_diagnoses.justification: Cholestatic LFT pattern (elevated conjugated bilirubin, ALP, GGT) can result from hepatotoxic medications.

differential_diagnoses.name: Acute viral hepatitis
differential_diagnoses.justification: Elevated AST and ALT alongside bilirubin rise may reflect viral hepatic injury, though the pattern is more cholestatic.

differential_diagnoses.name: Hematologic malignancy (e.g., acute leukemia)
differential_diagnoses.justification: July CBC shows leukocytosis with neutrophilia, marked thrombocytopenia, and abnormal differential, consistent with marrow infiltration.

differential_diagnoses.name: Parasitic infection or allergic reaction
differential_diagnoses.justification: Early‑April eosinophilia (8.1 %) points toward an eosinophilic response such as parasitosis or hypersensitivity.
